roedd yn y bwynt yn unrhyw ffordd, dyna'r enw o'r bwynt.
A oes gennych chi, oedd pobl yn y bwynt yng Nghymru yn fwy sgiliau yng nghymru gweithwyr?
Yn eich hun, yn eich hun ffordd, oes.

roedd angen i chi fod yn gweithio'r mecian.

fel holl a'r oed, mae'n cael ei wneud o'r ffell.

Felly, roeddech chi'n mynd yn y ffell ymlaen, o'r hyn o'r ffell, o'r hyn o'r ffell?
Nid, roeddwn yn mynd yn y ffell.
Why do you think you were given, they put you on the special?
Dwi ddim, dwi ddim.
Whether it was an availability, I'm not sure.
I never ever, I mean I learned how to use the ordinary machines,
but they were high powered, you see, high powered sewing machines,
not like little machines, the smaller machines you've got now.
They were industrial machines, industrial sewing machines.
We had the machines, we also had one section who were,
they did the whole garment right from start to finish,
but they were more advanced sewers.
When somebody came in the factory and started as a learner,
they had to start learning how to sew a particular piece,
and they did that for quite a while.
And then if they were any good, they went on to different sections,
and once they became proficient in what they were doing,
they could go on, and it was a piecework thing that they would do.
So they would go on to another section where these more industrial machines,
because the factory, you see, was laid out in rows of what we called benches,
and it was, you'd have the pathway down between,
and the girls would be almost back to back on their benches,
if you can answer. It's a bit hard to explain it,
but if you went into the factory and looked down,
there was a row of section there, then section there, another section there.
Then all along that wall were the tables where there were great big windows,
that was the cutting out section. They had to have the light, you see,
so where those windows were was ideal, and they were massive, heavy tables
where the cutting out was done.
And that went three quarters of the way down the entire length of the factory.
Is this what you saw when you went there on the first day?
On the first day I was overwhelmed, you know.
Oh gosh, you know, we were, if I remember rightly,
I can't remember, I think the lady who was my supervisor, Mary,
she'd been there a while, and she had to show me how to do things, you know,
and they sort of walk you through it at first,
and then you have to learn how to use the machine.
Trying to remember that first day, it's such a long time ago,
I find it hard to really picture it, you know,
because it became my way of life, I suppose you'd call it.
Did you have an interview, by the way, to go there?
Oh yes, yes.
And what did they ask you in the interview?
What was I interested in? My mother came with me, you know, as support,
and they just asked you what you were interested in,
what would you like to do, and to see interests, that was just the main thing.
They said, well, you know, we'd like you to start.
And you were sewing at home, weren't you?
I was doing small things, some of it's more so putting little things together,
embroidery, that sort of thing.
It wasn't actually putting a garment together, I hadn't done that, I'd never done that.
Did you use a sewing machine at home?
No, no, didn't have one.
My mother couldn't sew, she'd never been able to sew really,
but little things in school, when I was in school,
we used to do little bits of embroidery, and it was just using my hands.
I was very fond of crocheting and knitting, and I wasn't interested in that.
So I was using my hands in that respect, but this was a totally and entirely different thing.
You can't really picture it until you start doing it,
and it's something you either like it or you don't.
But fortunately I liked it.
I enjoyed the challenge, I suppose it would be, what do you say, challenge.
I found, well, as I say, I spent ten years at it.
I wanted to complete ten years, because when I left,
I only had six weeks to go before my first child was due.
But I wanted to complete my ten years, and that's why I finished up on the Christmas time,
and I said, I've done my ten years.
To me that was, I felt fine.
I'd put on weight obviously, but I was fine.
I was able to work right up.
Why was that important for you, do you think?
It was something I wanted to do.
I wanted to say I had completed my ten years.
To the day?
To the day, really, yes.
They didn't object to you working there, you see, as long as you were able to do the job.
But I'd gone from an overlock, and as I say, I went through different sections.
The last few years I was there, I was on the hemming machine.
I was on that.
I was actually, the special bench was in one section, but they extended it out.
I was working right by the door, the exit door, by the entrance and the exit door.
I was working there.
The only problem with that is on a cold day, if they left the door open, oh, I was caught in a draft.
It did affect my back, and I've severed my back for so many years.
I was going to ask you that about the conditions in the factory.
What would you say on the whole about the conditions, you know, light, heat, that kind of thing?
Quite adequate, really.
You had a chair with a back to it, and your work was put into the bins, as we called them.
You had a metal bin on your side of your machine, and the garment that you were either sewing or overlocking, whatever,
it was all put in the bin, and you took it out and packed it, because it was tied up in bundles.
You took it out and you did it, and then you put it in the finish section.
You had a bin the other side, a finish section, and you put it in there, and then it was passed on.
The supervisor would come round and collect it, pass it on to another section.
So it was, what affected a lot of people, I think, was the fact that you had a light on the needle.
Don't forget, if you're sewing, we would get a break about 11 o'clock, and then lunchtime you had your break,
and then you get a small break in the afternoon again.
But you see, constantly sewing, or constantly watching a needle up and down, or going round whatever, for so many hours,
you do get eye strain.
So do you think it affected your eyes over the years?
Well, I was already wearing glasses by then. I was very fond of reading, and of course, growing up where I grew up,
there was no electricity in the house that I was brought up in. It was only the old gas mantles.
And because I was a prolific reader, I'd go to bed with a candle and read.
And of course, it strained my eyes, but I was always wearing glasses by the time I left school.
So it didn't affect me too badly, but you know.
It affected your back, you think?
Oh, yes. When you bench over a machine, you sit in that position for a few hours, it tells on you.
But it's like everything else, you get used to it. After so long, you get used to things.
And you didn't think the conditions were really bad?
Oh, no. No. No.
There were times when you got a little bit fed up with it.
And as I say, we all go through different phases.
Management could jump on you. You'd be doing your best, and to them it wasn't enough.
They wanted to push you that little bit harder.
But we all went through different stages where, oh, I've had enough, I think, and they're looking for something else.
But we didn't. We stayed on to the end.
There were a few left because of one reason or another. People got married and left.
Others just got fed up with doing the job they were doing and wanted something different.
As I say, there were quite a few different reasons.
There was a lot going for it. I mean, we had our Christmas parties for children.
And that was enjoyable. We used to have it in the canteen.
We had a lovely canteen, a nice big canteen, and they were very good.
Did you used to eat in the canteen?
Oh, yes.
What was the food like?
Nothing too drastic, you know.
But they had a really good canteen.
The girls that worked there did their best.
We used to get bens and cakes and all the things in a break, and then lunchtime they put on a couple of meals.
Sometimes we, you know, cost-wise, because we weren't on big money,
sometimes we took our own sandwiches, which you could do.
Just buy a cup of tea. It was mostly tea then, not so much coffee.
But you could buy a cup of tea or you could buy a squash or something.
Excuse me.
And we'd have our own sandwiches, you know.
So it was mainly women working in the factory, was it?
Oh, yes. We had a couple. We had a...
I'm trying to think.
One, two, three, four.
On an average, you've just four men.
Two men in the stockroom.
The mechanic.
And one of the bosses.
Our main boss was Miss Grunfeld, who was the manageress of the factory.
Miss Muenitz was the office manager.
I've been trying to remember Mr Leo something or other was one of the managers.
He came in later. At first it was only Miss Muenitz who was in total control.
Mr Smith was the stockroom manager and he had a chap working with him, Jimmy.
I can't remember his surname. It was Jimmy.
But that was the only men. The rest were all girls.
How did you treat the men? Did some of the girls use to tease them?
No, no.
The only one we joked with was the chap who was under Mr Smith.
I think it was Jimmy, his name.
No, Mr Smith, you treated him with respect, you know.
The mechanic, he was just part of the scene.
He didn't have a lot to do with them really. It was mainly the girls.
By the way, I was going to ask you, was there a certain smell to the factory?
Do you remember any kind of smell? You mentioned the noise, but I was wondering.
Well, as I say, we used to have to clean our machines and you just have to oil it.
If you can smell material, yes, but it wasn't like an unpleasant smell at all.
You just didn't notice it really.
No, I didn't mean an unpleasant smell. What was the smell of the place?
Do you know, I can't even visualise it.
To me, no, I wouldn't have said it didn't really register.
How can I explain it? It's hard to try and describe something like that, but no.
Yes, you could smell the materials. When you cleaned and oiled your machine,
the end of the day sort of thing, then yes, you could smell that, but I wouldn't have said it smelled.
It's something that was there and you just took it for granted, I suppose.
Did you have a favourite job when you were there? What was your favourite work?
Actually, I suppose when it came to the Christmas party, I used to go out.
We had sort of, not a union, it was just welfare, I suppose you'd call it.
I was the lucky one who used to go with the manager, the mail manager at the time.
We used to organise a Christmas party for the children of the people who worked in the factory.
Well, as I didn't have any children, I used to take one of my cousins' son, put his name down,
because we used to have a nice party for them. They'd each get a present.
I used to go with the manager and go to a warehouse, have a list of the children and the ages,
and we used to say, all right, we've got five children aged six to seven, three of them are girls, so many boys,
and we'd have to get them. I used to love doing that. I really did love doing that.
So was it the management arranging the party, you'd say?
Well, they'd say to it, you know, when do you want your party? We'd pick out a date near Christmas.
The girls would all do the work. I can't even remember. I suppose the management paid for it. I can't really remember.
So there was the children's Christmas party?
It was the children's Christmas party. We used to have a dance. We used to organise a dance for our girls,
and I can remember one being in Cardiff, in what is now, I think, it's not there now. It was a theatre at one time.
We went upstairs and there was a dance hall up there, and we used to organise that, but that was for us. It was a Christmas dance.
Do you remember which theatre it was?
Well, it was down at the end of St Mary Street, and I remember we went upstairs for this one, but I can't remember the name of the place.
I'm saying it was a theatre where there was actually a main theatre. I'm not quite sure. My memory is very poor in remembering that, to be honest,
but I can remember going upstairs for this particular dance, and that's the photograph that I showed you, in my photographs, where it was taken in that place.
But I can't remember the name of it.
Did all the girls used to go to these?
Most of them did, yes. Most of them did. Some brought their boyfriends, and one lady that we had, she brought her daughter, you know.
But most of the girls used to go to the dance.
What kind of music was it?
Oh, during the big bands and rock and roll and all that sort of thing, you know.
Did you get some famous names playing?
No, no, no. I think it was a band that was perhaps registered there. To be honest, I can't remember much about it, although I know I went, because I've got a photograph to prove it,
but I've had a lot of years since then to forget about it, unfortunately.
So where did the children's parties used to happen?
We used to have that in the canteen. We used to set that up there. It was easy enough, you see, and we could use parts of the factory, the bottom end of the factory.
There wasn't a lot down there, so we could utilise that area if we wanted to, which we did very often, you know, we'd set up something down there.
But the canteen was, as I say, it was a good canteen, which was actually not in the building, not in the factory building.
It was a separate building altogether across the concourse, you know.
We came out through the exit doors and it was facing you, and it was a good size, really good size.
It had to be, because I mean, the breaks, we had to take the breaks in stages, you see.
They'd have the first section would go, and they'd alternate it from one time to another.
So our section, perhaps the one week would be on first, and the second week we'd be on second.
So they had to do it that way, for people to be served, because there were only so many working in the canteen, and you couldn't get all the girls in in one go.
How many girls were there, would you say?
In the canteen?
No, in...
Oh, in that? Well, as I say...
Hundreds, was it?
I'd say over hundreds, I think.
It's something you don't realise at the time, but quite a lot, because there were so many different sections, there were quite a lot of people there.
So I'm going to ask you about wages now then. Can you remember how much you have paid when you went to work there?
My first wage was £1.086.
And did you have a pay rise at all when you were there?
Yes. You were on trial, sort of thing, to start out with, you know. They said, put you on that wage to start with and see how you get on.
If you improve and you get on with your work, you get a pay rise. And I was only there about three or four months, I had a pay rise, because I'd got on with the job.
And how much did you get?
It wasn't a lot more, but it was something over £2, I think, then. But, I mean, the money then was totally different.
I mean, I'd never been money before. I used to give my mother a pound.
And because when I first started, I tried cycling to work, but that became a bit of a bore in the end, you know, and my poor old bike conked out, so I had to travel.
But because I had a slight rise, travel was a lot cheaper than it is now.
But I always tried to give my mother a pound towards my keep. And as I increased my wages, you know, with experience, my wages went up and up.
And I could manage a bit more then. But, I mean, it got in the end that I was earning more in piecework than I was in wages.
I was going to ask you about the piecework. So was that a good thing, do you think?
Oh, yes, yes. It encouraged you to do more. The better you worked, the harder you worked, the more you earned.
So it was beneficial for you in the end to be able to do that. There were sections that couldn't do it, you know, they could only, it was more so on the production side.
But they used me as a, I used to be timed to do the jobs. And they used to say to me, Macy, slow down when you're going, don't do your usual speed.
So that we'll get a bit of bonus at the end of it, because otherwise, if I went to my normal speed then, they wouldn't have had much in the way of bonuses.
So I'd have to hold back on the way I worked.
Did they have time and motion people in?
That was the man, I can't remember his name. Leo was his first name, but I can't remember his name. Anderson?
Oh, that's my failing. I never forget faces, but I'm terrible for trying to remember names. But he did the time and motion most of the time, you know.
That's what he came in to do. Of course he used me as the time and motion on the overlocker and on the pedding machine.
So, what was that? Can you explain that to me? How did that work?
Well, if it was for the overlocker inside of it, you get parts of a garment, which you have to overlock the seams.
So, he would say, I'd get the garment in my hand and he'd say, right, and he'd press, he had a watch and press it.
And then, while I was doing it, that watch would be going. When I'd finished doing the particular job, he'd stop the watch and he'd jot it down.
When it came to the hemming of the garment, the same thing applied. As I'd pick up the garment, go, press the button, and then as I'd finished the garment, press the button.
And then, he used to take those times and work out what a garment was worth by the time it was finished.
Say, for example, if I did one dress in four minutes and it was worth 50p, this is just rough ideas, because they didn't tell us, they just timed us.
But the more we worked, the harder we worked, and the more we did, it became beneficial for us, rather than just a basic wage.
It was to encourage you to do more, to produce more, really.
